questions.text: In the given graph of a normal menstrual cycle, the mark 'X' represents levels of which of the following hormones?
questions.solution:
In the given menstrual cycle graph, the mark 'X' represents levels of progesterone.

The menstrual cycle consists of three phases: The proliferative phase, the secretory phase, and the menstrual phase.

The proliferative phase is estrogen-dominant and lasts from the end of menstruation to ovulation. It results in the proliferation of endometrial glands and thickened endometrium.

The secretory or progestational phase is progesterone dominant which converts the thickened, estrogen-primed endometrium to a richly vascularized, glycogen-filled tissue for early nourishment of a developing embryo. If fertilization and implantation do not occur, the corpus luteum degenerates and a new follicular phase and menstrual phase begin again.

The menstrual phase is characterized by the discharge of blood and endometrial debris from the vagina due to the withdrawal of progesterone and the degeneration of the corpus luteum (CL).

questions.text: In the image given below, the weight and height of a child are plotted against his age in years. Identify the correct statement.

choices.text: WHO growth charts used now are developed by National Center for Health Statistics (NCHS)
Short stature is defined as a height below 5th percentile
Puberty in this child will be normal
Bone age of this child is less than chronological age

questions.solution:
Bone age of this child is less than chronological age, as seen in cases of constitutional delay.

As seen in the graph, the child was short initially, but the final height is within normal range. Hence, this child has constitutional delay.

Other options:

  • The WHO growth charts are based on Multicentre Growth Reference Study (MGRS). National Center for Health Statistics (NCHS) developed growth charts
  • were used in the past.
  • Short stature is defined as a height below the third percentile or more than 2 standard deviations below the median height for age and gender (<-2 SD) according to the population standard.
  • Puberty will be delayed in this child.

questions.text: Read the pedigree chart and identify the pattern of transmission.
questions.solution:
The pattern of inheritance shown in the image is X linked recessive pattern of inheritance.

Clues for diagnosis of the pattern of inheritance as X-linked recessive:

  • Males are affected and females are carriers.
  • No male-to-male transmission. Females transmit the disease.
  • Females transmit the mutated genes to 50% of the males.
  • Affected males have carrier daughters and unaffected sons.

Related Pearl: Pedigree chart for different inheritance patterns

 

Autosomal Dominant Disorders:

  • With every autosomal dominant disorder, some patients do not have affected parents. Such patients owe their disorder to new mutations involving either the egg or the sperm from which they were derived.
  • Clinical features can be modified by variations in penetrance and expressivity.
  • In many conditions, the age at onset is delayed, and symptoms and signs may not appear until adulthood (as in Huntington disease).

X-linked Recessive Conditions:

  • All sex-linked disorders are X-linked, and almost all are recessive.
  • Several genes are located in the “male-specific region of Y;” all these are related to spermatogenesis.
  • Males with mutations affecting the Y-linked genes are usually infertile, and hence, there is no Y-linked inheritance.
  • An affected male does not transmit the disorder to his sons, but all daughters are carriers.
  • Sons of heterozygous women have, of course, a one-in-two chance of receiving the mutant gene.
  • Heterozygous females express the disorder partially because of random inactivation of one X chromosome.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding phase Ib of a cystometrogram?

choices.text: It is due to the elasticity of bladder
It is due to the plasticity the bladder has
The graph is flat due to the contractility of the bladder
Micturition occur at the start of Ib

questions.solution:
The true statement regarding phase Ib in the cystometrogram is that segment Ib is due to plasticity of the badder. Plasticity is the ability of an object to deform its shape without breaking.

Cystometrogram is a plot of intravesical pressure against the volume of fluid in the bladder. The curve shows three segments:

  • Ia- initial slight rise in pressure when the first increments in the volume are produced
  • Ib- long, nearly flat segment as further increments are produced
  • II- sudden, sharp rise in pressure as the micturition reflex is triggered.
  • The dotted line- pressure-volume relation if the micturition had not occurred.

The flatness of segment Ib is a demonstration of the law of Laplace. The law of Laplace states that the pressure (P) in a spherical viscus is equal to twice the wall tension (T) divided by the radius (R). This is expressed as P= 2T/R. In the blad­der, the tension increases as the bladder get filled. Since the radius also increases because of the plasticity of the bladder, there is only a slight increase in pressure until the bladder is relatively full.

The first urge to void is felt at a bladder volume of about 150 mL. A marked sense of fullness is felt at a bladder volume of 400ml.

Micturition reflex is the result of sensory signals from the stretch receptors in the bladder wall, which are conducted to the sacral segments of the cord through the pelvic nerves and then efferent signals conducts back again to the bladder through the parasympathetic nerve fibers.

The micturition reflex pathway is given below.

Other options:

Option A: Elasticity refers to the ability of an object to return to its original state after being deformed by an external force. Elasticity of bladder is responsible for the recoil shrinking of the bladder after micturition. 

Option C: Contractility is the ability to contract and increase the tension or decrease the length or dimensions. Contractility of the bladder is responsible for the voiding of urine. It doesn't contribute to the flat curve in Ib.

Option D: Voiding starts at the end of Ib and the start of II.

questions.text: This is the partograph of a primigravida in labor. What is the next line of management?

choices.text: Induction of labor by mechanical methods

questions.solution:
Cesarean section is the next line of management as the plotting on the above partograph has crossed the action line.

Partograph is analysed using alert and action lines. When the graph crosses the action line, active intervention should be initiated.

Labor is divided into a latent phase (average of 8 hrs in primi and 6 hrs in multigravida) and an active phase.

Clinically the active phase starts at ≥6 cm dilatation, and progress should be no slower than 1 cm/hr.

A 4-hour wait is recommended before intervention when the active phase is slow.

questions.text: The relative risks for vaccines A and B are 0.5 and 2.0 respectively. Identify which of the following graphs represent them correctly.
questions.solution:
Graphs 1 and 2 correctly represent the relative risks of the vaccines.

The relative risks of vaccines A and B are 0.5 and 2.

Graph 1: The 1st bar is at 0.5, and the 2nd bar is at 2. 

Graph 2: The 1st bar is at 0.5, and the 2nd bar is at 2. 

Graph 3: The 1st bar is at 0, and the 2nd bar is at 2. 

Therefore, graph 3 is wrong and graphs 1 and 2 correctly depict the given scenario.

 

Relative Risk:

  • The ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called the risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR of 2 or higher indicates a 100% increase in risk.

Related Pearl: Relative and attributable risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR >1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 or higher indicates a >/=100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ c/(c+d)] where, 
  Cancer
Exposure   yes no
yes a b
no c d

 

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

 

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause to effect, as exposure has occured but not disease.
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a Cohort Study
    • Types
      • Prospective cohort studies (concurrent cohort studies)
      • Retrospective cohort studies (historical cohort study)
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages and disadvantages

Advantages

Disadvantages

Incidence can be calculated.

Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at same time.

Provides direct estimate of relative risk

Calculation of dose-response ratio

Minimization of certain biases

Cannot be used for uncommon diseases

Uses a large population

Takes a long time to complete

Many common administrative problems

Attrition is high.

Selection of subjects is difficult.

Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate.

Tend to be expensive.

Tends to alter behaviour of subjects: Hawthorne effect.

Ethical problems

questions.text:
A biochemistry resident plots a graph while studying the effect of an inhibitor on an enzymatic reaction. Which of the following statements is false, with respect to the following graph that he has plotted?

Km: The substrate concentration at which velocity is half the maximum.

Vmax: The maximum velocity of a reaction.

v0: Reaction velocity

[S]: Substrate concentration

choices.text: Reaction is with a non-competitive inhibitor
Inhibitor binds to the enzyme in location other than the active site
Vmax decreases and Km is unchanged
Can be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration

questions.solution:
The given graph represents a reaction with a non-competitive inhibitor and it cannot be overcome by increasing the concentration of the substrate.

The above graph is called the 'Lineweaver-Burk plot' or 'double reciprocal' plot. 1/v0 is plotted versus 1/[S] and a straight line is obtained. This plot can be used to calculate Km and Vmax as well as to determine the mechanism of action of enzyme inhibitors.

In non-competitive inhibition, Vmax decreases (or 1/Vmax increases) but Km is unchanged. Hence the graphs of inhibited and uninhibited reactions have the same x-intercepts (converge at -1/Km) but different y-intercepts.

In contrast to competitive inhibitors, noncompetitive inhibitors bind to enzymes in locations away from the active site. For this reason, the degree of inhibition is based solely upon the concentration of the inhibitor, and increasing the substrate concentrations does not compete with or change the inhibition. Therefore, unlike the increase in Km seen with competitive inhibition, in noncompetitive inhibition, Vmax decreases while Km usually remains the same. While competitive inhibitors can be overcome at a sufficiently high substrate concentration (i.e, reversible), non-competitive inhibition is irreversible and cannot be overcome by increasing the concentration of the substrate.

Related Pearl: Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Reversible inhibitors are of two types:

  • Competitive inhibitors
  • Non-Competitive inhibitors

Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Competitive inhibitors

Non-Competitive inhibitors

Succinate dehydrogenase is inhibited by Malonate

Pyruvate kinase is inhibited by alanine

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically similar & have same shape

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically not similar & have different shape

Inhibitor binds to active site

Inhibitor binds away from active site, i.e., at allosteric site

Inhibitor does not change the shape of the active site

Inhibitor changes the shape of the active site

Increase in substrate concentration reduces the inhibition

Increase in substrate concentration does not affect the inhibition

Vmax remains constant

Vmax decreases

Km Increases

Km remains constant

questions.text: What type of data does the image given below represent?
questions.solution:
The given image is of a histogram. It is used to represent frequency distributions of continuous quantitative data.

Nominal and ordinal data can be represented by a bar chart.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following is a histogram of cholesterol levels from the Framingham Heart Study.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: This is the graph depicting the filterability of dextran through the kidney, 1 representing complete filtration and 0 representing no filtration. Choose the substance A, B, C respectively.
questions.solution:
In the given graph, the order of filterability is A>B>C, which likely indicates that the substances are Polycationic, Neutral, Polyanionic.

The glomerular filtration barrier is negatively charged, which will repel most of the negative charged (anionic substances). Whereas, the cationic substances are easily filtered.

Hence, the order of filterability would be: Polycationic > Neutral > Polyanionic, represented by A, B, and C in the graph shown.

 

The glomerular filtration barrier consists of:

  • The endothelium of the capillary
  • A basement membrane - lamina densa- electron-dense layer and contains type IV collagen, lamina rara interna and externa contains glycosaminoglycan heparan sulphate which has a negative charge. 
  • A layer of epithelial cells (podocytes) surrounding the outer surface of the capillary basement membrane.

questions.text: Identify the ions A and B based on conductance graph of a neuron shown below:
questions.solution:
Channel A: Na+, Channel B: K+

Na+ channels are fast activating and are responsible for depolarization phase of action potential.

K+ channels are slow activating and open for prolonged duration than the sodium channels. They are responsible for repolarization phase of action potential. Also, the postassium channels return slowly to their closed state, which is responsible for after-hyperpolarization.

The sequence of events during the action potential occur in 7 steps as described below.

1. Resting state - Both channels are closed

2. Na+ channels open in response to depolarizing stimulus. Sodium enters into the cell. The membrane reaches threshold potential.

3. The sodium influx causes opening of more sodium channels through positive feedback mechanism. Rapid depolarization occurs.

4. Sodium conductance decreases.

5. Na+ channels close and K+ channels open. Repolarization occurs.

6. Sodium channels are reset, and are ready to respond to another depolarizing stimulus (relative refractory period). During this phase, the potassium channels remain open and slowly return to closed state causing after-hyperpolarization.

7. Both channels are closed. The membrane returns to RMP.

questions.text: In the following osmotic fragility curve, ‘A’ occurs in _________.
questions.solution:
In the given osmotic fragility curve, the green-shaded region is the normal zone of red blood cell hemolysis. Here, curve A is more towards the left, indicating that RBCs have an increased osmotic fragility. When there is an increase in osmotic fragility, hemolysis occurs at a higher concentration of NaCl. Curve A signifies a higher concentration of NaCl in this graph which occurs in hereditary spherocytosis.

In thalassemia and sickle-cell anemia, on the other hand, the red cells become more resistant to osmotic lysis due to which there is a decrease in osmotic fragility. Hence, the curve will shift to the right.

questions.text: Name the principle of the test shown below:
questions.solution:
The given image depicts a Duochrome test based on chromatic aberration. It is used to refine the final sphere in subjective refraction.

  • The patient is asked to compare the clarity of the letters on the green and the red side.
  • If a myopic sees the letters of the green side clearer, he is overcorrected. So, +0.25 D sphere is added or -0.25D is removed.
  • However, if a myopic sees the letters on the red side clearer, he is undercorrected and -0.25 D sphere is added.
  • With optimal spherical correction, the letters on the red and green halves of the chart appear equally clear.

questions.text: An oxygen hemoglobin dissociation curve of a 30-year-old athlete was recorded. If curve 3 represents the dissociation curve during rest, how would the graph shift if he was exercising?
questions.solution:
From the given scenario, during exercise, the oxygen hemoglobin curve shifts considerably towards the right and is denoted by the curve 4.

Curve 3 represents the normal oxygen hemoglobin curve during rest. 

Conditions that cause a right shift (curve 3 to curve 4) in the oxygen hemoglobin curve are: (Conditions with the increased requirement of O2 - metabolically active tissues)

  • Hypoxia and Hypercarbia - Metabolically active tissues utilize O2 and tissues produce CO2
  • ↓ pH - Secondary to increased CO2 production
  • ↑ in temperature, heat
  • ↑ in 2,3-DPG - increased anaerobic glycolysis

Conditions that cause a left shift (curve 3 to curve 2)  in the oxygen hemoglobin dissociation curve are:

  • Decreased carbon dioxide
  • ↑ pH of the blood
  • ↓ in the temperature of the body

Curve 1 represents the Myoglobin-O2 binding curve. It is a rectangular hyperbola (unlike a sigmoid curve of the oxygen-hemoglobin curve). This is because it only has a single oxygen binding site. It is present in muscles in large amounts and can provide oxygen to muscles even at low blood oxygen levels.

Related Pearl: Factors affecting 2,3 -DPG

↑ in 2, 3-DPG ↓ in 2, 3-DPG
  • Chronic hypoxia
  • Anemia
  • Accilimitization (high altitude)
  • Thyroid hormone
  • Growth hormone
  • Androgens
  • Exercise
  • Stored blood
  • Acidosis

questions.text: Identify the virus in the following transmission cycle:
questions.solution:
Transmission cycle of the Japanese encephalitis virus is shown above.

Humans are the dead-end hosts for the Japanese encephalitis virus. The disease is transmitted by the bite of Culex mosquitoes, specifically Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui (common in India) species.

Japanese encephalitis follows bird-arthropod-human transmission.

JE virus infects several extra-human hosts, e.g., pigs and birds (like pond herons).  The basic cycles of transmission are:

 (a)Pig → Mosquito  → Pig

(b) Bird → Mosquito → Bird

Herons act as reservoir hosts and pigs as amplifier hosts. The control measures include mosquito control, locating piggeries away from the human dwellings and vaccinating pigs.

Other options:

Nipah virus is a zoonotic virus, which is transmitted by animals to humans. 

Transmission:

  • Unprotected exposure to the secretions from the pigs, or unprotected contact with the tissue of a sick animal.
  • Consumption of fruits or fruit products (such as raw date palm juice) contaminated with urine or saliva from infected fruit bats.
  • Human-to-human transmission through close contact with people's secretions and excretions.

The image depicts the life cycle of the Nipah virus.

Ebola virus belongs to the family filoviridae and is transmitted by bats.

  • Transmission is through contact with infectious bodily fluids or organs of animals like chimpanzees and monkeys.
  • Human to human transmission is through blood or body fluids of an infected symptomatic person.
  • It can remain in semen for up to 3 months, although sexual transmission has not been reported yet.

Zika virus is transmitted to humans primarily through the bite of an infected Aedes species mosquito (Ae. aegypti and Ae. albopictus).

  • Anyone who lives in or travels to a region with risk of Zika infection, and has not already been infected with Zika virus can get it from mosquito bites. Once a person has been infected, they are likely to be protected from future infections
  • A pregnant woman can pass Zika virus to her fetus during pregnancy. Zika is a cause of microcephaly and other severe fetal brain defects. Zika virus has also been found in breast milk. Possible Zika virus infections have been identified in breastfeeding babies, but Zika virus transmission through breast milk has not been confirmed.
  • Zika can be passed through sexual intercourse, even if the infected person does not have symptoms at the time.
  • To date, there have not been any confirmed blood transfusion transmission cases in the United States. There are reports of laboratory acquired Zika virus infections, although the route of transmission was not clearly established in all cases

questions.text: What is the location of the complexes shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image shows the electron transport chain (ETC) which is located on the inner mitochondrial membrane. 

The electron transport chain (ETC) is a specialized set of electron carriers that can accept electrons. Energy-rich molecules like glucose are oxidized to produce water and carbon dioxide. The intermediate substrates in these reactions can pass on electrons to certain coenzymes like nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) and flavin adenine dinucleotide (FADH2).

The energy from electron transfer is used to move H+ through the inner mitochondrial membrane. The H+ gradient thus produced results in the production of ATP. ATP synthesis together with electron transport is known as oxidative phosphorylation. 

Option B - Outer mitochondrial membrane has acyl-CoA synthetase and glycerol phosphate acyltransferase.

Option C - Mitochondrial matrix has citric acid cycle enzymes, β-oxidation enzymes, and pyruvate dehydrogenase.

Option D - Intermembrane space has adenylyl kinase and creatine kinase. It is filled with H+ creating a proton gradient. 

 The reactions in oxidative phosphorylation and the arrangement of complexes that form the ETC are shown below.

Related Pearl: Electron transport chain: components and its inhibitors

Related Pearl: Reducing Equivalents and Their Uses

Reducing agents

Uses

NADPH

Lipid synthesis

Cholesterol synthesis 

Fatty acid chain elongation

Cytochrome P450 hydroxylation of aromatic compounds, steroids, alcohols, and drugs

NADH

Metabolizes alcohol

Glycolysis & Krebs cycle

Oxidative phosphorylation

β- Oxidation of fatty acid

Catalyzes reactions in muscle and liver cells

Electron Transport Chain

FADH2

Krebs cycle

Electron Transport Chain

Oxidative Phosphorylation

Cytochrome P450 hydroxylase cycle

β-Oxidation of fatty acid

questions.text: A pressure-volume diagram of the left ventricle is given below. Calculate the stroke volume considering the heart rate as 65 beats per minute.
questions.solution:
The stroke volume of this pressure-volume diagram is 70 mL.

The points in the graph indicate the following events of the cardiac cycle:

  • Point 1: Opening of the mitral valve. The corresponding reading on the graph denotes end-systolic volume (ESV).
  • Point 2: Closing of the mitral valve. The corresponding reading on the graph denotes end-diastolic volume (EDV).
  • Point 3: Opening of the aortic valve.
  • Point 4: Closing of the aortic valve.

Stroke volume is the amount of blood that the heart pumps out with each beat. It is about 70 mL from each ventricle in resting conditions.

In a pressure-volume diagram, stroke volume (SV) can be calculated using the values of ESV (50 mL) and EDV (120 mL):

Stroke volume = End diastolic volume – End systolic volume

Therefore, SV = 120 - 50 = 70 mL.

Cardiac output can be calculated from the given data using the formula:  Cardiac output = Stroke volume x heart rate

Therefore, in this case, cardiac output = 70 x 65 = 4550 mL.

questions.text: Analyze the graphs given below on different occupational groups and the chance of developing fever amongst each group. Which of the following groups has the highest chance of developing fever?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a component bar graph(A) and a pie chart(B). The pie chart shows the different groups and their percentage among the total workers, whereas the component bar graph shows the chance of them developing a fever. The highest chance of developing a fever is around 90% , which is seen among white-collar jobs as evident from the component bar graph.

The chance of developing fever in other groups are Industrial workers-50%, Farmers- 50% and Houseweives-around 20%. If the question was on the group having the highest proportion among the total workers, then it would be industrial workers, from the pie graph.

Component bar graph:

The bars can be divided into two or more parts where each part represents a certain item, proportional to the magnitude of that particular item (males and females in this image).

It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data.

The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups. Frequency polygon and Ogive can be constructed using a histogram, not a component bar chart

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following is a histogram of cholesterol levels from the Framingham Heart Study.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: The graph below shows the relationship between the log[Dose] and the response of three drugs A, B, and C. Which of the following options is true in regards to the drugs' efficacy?
questions.solution:
In the log dose-response curve, the perpendicular height represents the drug efficacy.

Therefore, Drug C has the least efficacy. Both Drug A and Drug B have the highest efficacy that is the maximum effect produced by the drug. Thus, in the above image, the efficacy is Drug A = Drug B > Drug C.

Efficacy:

  • It is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug.
  • It reflects the capacity of the drug to activate a receptor and produce the response.
  • In the log dose-response curve, the perpendicular height represents the drug efficacy. Thus, in the above image, the efficacy is Drug A = Drug B > Drug C.

Potency:

  • It is defined as the amount of drug needed to produce a given response. 
  • A highly potent drug evokes a given response at low concentrations and vice-versa.
  • The more the curve is on the left in a log dose-response curve (DRC), the greater is its potency. Thus, in the above image, Drug A is more potent. The potency is Drug A >Drug B> Drug C.(option B)

questions.text: The diagram below shows the pressure-volume curves for 3 different lungs. Which of the following is the best representation of compliance between the three lungs?
questions.solution:
The given diagram depicts the change in volume with a change in intrapleural pressure, which is nothing but compliance. Here, the change is more (steep curve) with B and least (flat curve) with C. 

The pressure-volume relationship is the fundamental relation between the work of breathing and lung mechanics.

  • The “stiffer” lung displays a more horizontal curve (C), meaning that it takes a greater pressure to achieve the same inflation volume compared with a normal lung (A). These lungs are called less compliant.
  • Curve (B) is more compliant as it takes lesser pressure to achieve the same inflation volume compared to normal (A).

Applied aspect:

Compliance is increased in emphysema. The mechanism is shown in the flow chart below.

Compliance is decreased in case of pulmonary edema or fibrosis.

questions.text: What does number 9 in the given diagram related to hypertension denote?
questions.solution:
The above diagram depicts the rule of halves, which is observed in hypertension, and "number 9" denotes adequately treated subjects.

The rule of halves depicts that only about half of the hypertensive subjects in the general population of most developed countries were aware of the condition and only half of those aware are being treated and only half of those being treated are considered to be adequately treated. 

The numbers in the diagram denote the following:

  1. Whole community
  2. Normotensive subjects
  3. Hypertensive subjects
  4. Undiagnosed hypertension
  5. Diagnosed hypertension
  6. Diagnosed but untreated
  7. Diagnosed and treated
  8. Inadequately treated
  9. Adequately treated

questions.text:
The growth parameters of an 18-month-old girl baby were charted as shown in the image below. This child can be classified to have ____.

ICDS - Integrated child development scheme
questions.solution:
From the World Health Organization (WHO) growth chart  (length for age), the child falls below -3SD and is classified to have chronic malnutrition/ severe stunting.

Low height for age (height for age < -2SD) in children indicates chronic malnutrition and stunting. 

Classification of nutritional status depending on the anthropometry (height/length for age): 

Classification Criteria
Moderate stunting (or) moderate chronic malnutrition Height/length-for-age < –2 SD and > –3 SD
Severe stunting (or) severe chronic malnutrition Height/length-for-age < –3 SD

The nutritional status of a child is assessed in terms of anthropometry:

The World Health Organization (WHO) has established international standards for normal child growth from birth to 5 years of age. The normalization of the anthropometric measures is done in terms of z-scores (standard deviation scores). The anthropometric indicators are marked in a growth chart which is compared with a reference curve.

The anthropometric measures used are weight for age, height for age, weight for height, BMI, and mid-upper arm circumference.

  • Low weight-for-height, or wasting, indicates acute malnutrition. It is also mentioned as wasting.
  • High weight-for-height indicates overweight.
  • Low height-for-age, or stunting, indicates chronic malnutrition. This is the best indicator of long-term nutritional status in the pediatric population. 
  • Low weight-for-age indicates acute or chronic malnutrition. It does not differentiate between wasting and stunting. Hence, it has limited clinical significance.

Related Pearl: World Health Organization (WHO) classification of nutritional status of infants and children

Nutritional status
Criteria (from birth to 5 years)

Obese

Weight-for-height/length >3 SD

BMI-for-age >3 SD
Overweight

Weight-for-height/length >2 SD and ≤3 SD

BMI-for-age >2 SD and ≤3 SD
Moderately underweight Weight-for-age <–2 SD and ≥–3 SD
Severely underweight Weight-for-age <–3 SD
Moderate acute malnutrition

Weight-for-height/length ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD

BMI-for-age ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD

Mid-upper arm circumference ≥115 mm and <125 mm
Severe acute malnutrition

Weight-for-height/length <– 3 SD

BMI-for-age <– 3 SD

Mid-upper arm circumference <115 mm

Bilateral pitting edema
Moderately stunted (or) moderate chronic malnutrition Height/Length-for-age ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD
Severely stunted (or) severe chronic malnutrition Height/Length-for-age <–3 SD
Moderately wasted Weight-for-height/length ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD
Severely wasted Weight-for-height/length <-3 SD

SD - Standard deviation (from the median)

questions.text: Which of the following skeletal muscle relaxants exhibit the following response to the 'train of four protocol' used in the clinical assessment of neuromuscular blockade?
questions.solution:
Succinylcholine exhibits the above-given response to the 'train of four protocol' used in the clinical assessment of neuromuscular blockade.

Train of four protocol is one of the methods used in the clinical assessment of neuromuscular blockade. It is done by stimulating the ulnar nerve with a stimulus and watching the contractile responses in the adductor pollicis muscle. Four successive stimuli of 2Hz strength are given at fixed time intervals and the response achieved is plotted as a graph.

  Non-depolarizing blockers Depolarizing blockers
Fade phenomenon  Present 

Phase 1: Absent

Phase 2: Present 
Mechanism

Initial stimulus: Amount of Ach released is large enough to compete with the drug at the motor endplate causing maximal contraction of the muscle.

Successive stimuli: Amount of Ach released is insufficient to compete with the drug and results in sequentially diminished contractions

Phase 1: No competition between Sch and Ach. Sch acts like Ach at its receptors, but is not as easily metabolized by acetylcholinesterases resulting in persistent depolarisation. 

Phase 2: When the dose of Sch is increased maximally, it also exhibits a fade phenomenon.

questions.text: What is the angle at which the letters in Snellen’s chart subtend on the nodal point of eye?
questions.solution:
At the given distance, each letter subtends an angle of 5 min at the nodal point of the eye

Snellen’s chart is used for distant vision.

Patient should read the chart at a distance of 6 m.

The image above shows Snellen's chart.

questions.text: A patient being examined by you in the OPD describes the image below on the Amsler grid test. In which of the given conditions is this phenomenon noted?
questions.solution:
The image shows metamorphopsia seen in posterior uveitis.

Metamorphopsia is a condition in which patients perceive distorted images of the object. In posterior uveitis, it occurs due to macular edema.

Various visual symptoms in posterior uveitis/choroiditis:

  • Defective vision
  • Black spots floating in front of the eye
  • Micropsia
  • Macropsia
  • Positive scotoma

questions.text: A post-mortem cooling graph is plotted. What is the ideal shape of this graph?
questions.solution:
The graph plotted during post-mortem cooling is ideally sigmoid or inverted S-shaped. 

Algor mortis/postmortem cooling is one of the early changes occurring after death. After death, the body loses heat mainly by conduction and convection. Up to the first hour, a temperature plateau may be seen due to the heat generated by residual metabolic activities of dying tissues. This is followed by a linear rate of cooling over the next 12 to 16 hours. The temperature rarely reaches the ambient temperature, most likely due to bacterial action with decomposition setting in. 

The graph with the changes occurring after death plotted against time is as follows:

questions.text: The following diagram charts the HDL values in a given population. What is the statistical diagram used here?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Frequency polygons.

Frequency polygons:

  • Frequency polygons are used for ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient comes to the OPD with a history significant for a mood disorder. Her moods can be charted as done in the image given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing 4 episodes of depression and 2 episodes of mania within 1 year, points towards a diagnosis of rapid cycling bipolar disorder. 

It is diagnosed when the patient has 4 or more episodes of depression and/or mania or hypomania within one year. There must be less than 2 weeks of normalcy between the episodes or an immediate shift between the symptoms with no intervening normal mood.

Risk factors:

  • Female patients
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Alcoholism or substance abuse
  • Antidepressants (if used without mood stabilizers)
  • Cyclothymia
  • Bipolar II disorder

The drug of choice for rapid cycling disorder is valproate. 

Note: If the phases of mania and depression alternate very rapidly in a matter of hours or days then the condition is known as ultra-rapid cycling disorder.

questions.text: Identify the hormone demonstrating the depicted fluctuations:
questions.solution:
Growth hormone demonstrates the depicted fluctuations. Growth hormone is secreted in a pulsatile fashion, with increase during strenuous exercise and during the early period of sleep, (Non-REM Sleep) as shown in the graph. It is reduced during the later stages of sleep. (REM Sleep)

Other options:

Option A: ACTH levels are high in the early morning and low in late evening. 

Option C: TSH is secreted in pulses, but the fluctuations are less in comparison to other pituitary hormones because of the low amplitude of the pulses and the relatively long half-life of TSH.

Option D: Prolactin is secreted in a pulsatile fashion, with the highest secretory peak between 4:00 and 6:00 a.m. (REM Sleep)

questions.text: The given image represents  which  of the following ?
questions.solution:
The above image represents a hypnogram. It is a graph that depicts the stages of sleep as a function of time. It provides a visual representation of sleep structure and is useful in the diagnosis of various sleep disorders. 

Other options:

  • An electroencephalogram is the depiction of the electrical activity of the surface of the brain. Different waveforms (alpha, beta, theta, delta) are produced depending on the functional status of the brain.
  • Polysomnography is a muti parametric test that is considered as the gold standard in the diagnosis of sleep disorders. It is a continuous recording of biophysiological changes that occur during sleep.
  • Epworth sleep assessment scale is a questionnaire used to quantify daytime sleepiness. It determines how frequently a patient is likely to doze off in 8 commonly encountered situations. It is a subjective assessment and hence less reliable.

questions.text: What does the area between the dotted lines in graph indicate?
questions.solution:
The area between the dotted lines in the graph shows a therapeutic window. It is the range of steady-state concentrations of drug that provides therapeutic efficacy with minimal toxicity.

The therapeutic index (TI) describes a relationship between the doses of a drug that causes lethal or toxic effects with the dose that causes therapeutic effects. It is also called therapeutic ratio.

Mathematically, you can calculate TI by following way:

Therapeutic Index = LD50/ED50 (or) Therapeutic Index = TD50/ED50

Where,

  • LD50 (Median Lethal dose) is the minimum amount of drug that causes adverse effects in 50% of the population. LD50  could also be replaced with Toxic dose (TD50).
  • ED50 (Median Effective dose) is the quantity of a drug that can produce desired therapeutic effects in 50% of the population.
